conclusion: To determine the ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity of the basketball during its collision with the ground, we need to analyze the motion of the basketball before and after the collision, taking into account the effects of air resistance.
The basketball is dropped from rest at height H.
The gravitational force acting on the basketball is mg.
The air resistance force is λmg.
Using the work-energy principle, the net work done on the basketball as it falls from height H to the ground is W_net = -λmgH.
The initial potential energy at height H is mgH.
The final kinetic energy just before collision is 1/2mv_1^2 = mgH - λmgH = mgH(1 - λ).
Solving for v_1 gives v_1 = sqrt(2gH(1 - λ)).
The basketball rebounds to a height h.
The velocity just after collision is v_2.
The work done against air resistance during the rebound is W_net = -λmgh.
The initial kinetic energy just after collision is 1/2mv_2^2.
The final potential energy at height h is mgh.
Solving for v_2 gives 1/2mv_2^2 = mgh(1 - λ) and v_2 = sqrt(2gh(1 - λ)).
The ratio v_2/v_1 is sqrt(2gh(1 - λ))/sqrt(2gH(1 - λ)) = sqrt(h/H).
The ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity of the basketball during its collision with the ground is sqrt(h/H).
